head.title: The Talk; Once Upon a Mattress

hedline.hl1: The Talk; Once Upon a Mattress

block.p: I am Patty.
I am Patty.
I am much older than 6.
I am a city grown-up.
I live in my own apartment.
But one night I got to sleep in a store called Hastens. They sell beds.
Hastens is enormously enormous.
And it has maybe 14 beds.
There is a bed that goes up and down and wriggles all your protoplasm when you push a button.1
And there is a round bed.2
And there is a bed that comes with two little tables on each side so you can have a place for all the things you have to have like your root beer.3
There is even a crib for a baby but I am not a baby. As I said, I am much older than 6.
And did I tell you there is a bed that costs $59,750?4
No, no, no. The mattress is not stuffed with saffron or hard-to-get stem cells or $59,750. It is stuffed with genuine horsehair, which, you must understand, is the best stuff for sleeping on.5
Especially if you are a horse.

Still, if you do not share my opinion that $59,750 is a lot of money for something you keep on the floor, then I am guessing you are the big boss of a hedge fund or that you live among the haut monde.
Paul is my main friend.
Paul likes to watch television.
So we hop up on a bed that has a giant TV in front of it.
And we watch a movie called ''Sleepless in Seattle.''
It is a very good movie.
Though, between you and me, it has nothing whatsoever to do with slumber.
Do you know what else?
We order Japanese food and eat it in bed when we watch TV.
